ep-593.speaker: ira glass

ep-593.act_title: Prologue

ep-593.utterance: I'm very happy today.

ep-593.act_title: Prologue
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: If you heard our radio show last week, you know that we went to refugee camps all over Greece. There are 57,000 refugees in Greece, most of them escaping violence in Syria, Afghanistan, and Iraq hoping to get to Germany and other countries in Europe. But unless the politics change dramatically, they'll probably be stuck in Greece for a long time-- six months easily, maybe a lot more. The Greek government is building these camps to last for years, just in case.

ep-593.act_title: Prologue
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: And the camps, people kind of know that. But mostly I think they don't like to admit it to themselves. Today on our show we have stories of people trying to have semi-normal parts of their lives in a place that is not normal at all. From WBEZ Chicago, It's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: You do? I could tell.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Yeah, he writes lots of poems and recites them to me.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: We should really--

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: I asked Tarek if he would read us one of his love poems at some point.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Not right now, this second.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: I figured we'd just do it when we came back the next day. But then when we did go back the next day, our fixer went to find them and came back alone, with some news.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: What, are you kidding? Hold on one second. Wait-- wait-- wait-- wait.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Our fixer, Ammar, said he had found Tarek all by himself in the tent, deeply upset.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: He's very furious right now because they took his girlfriend or fiance so whatever, yeah.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: The sister and aunt did?

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: Yeah, the sister and the aunt took Hadeah-- Hadeah?

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: Hadil, but yeah, she was gone. Tarek wouldn't talk to me about it. He said no more recording. So Ammar sat with him in the tent for a long time, and finally convinced him to spill out the whole story.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: Maybe he's drunk right now. He looks like drunk. So he told me that the aunt had bring like four men and attack him and beat him-- beat him. He looks like this.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Bent over.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker

ep-593.speaker: sean cole

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: He don't want to talk about it.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: They went to go smuggling.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: To go smuggling?

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: Yeah, of course.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: That is, her family took her with them to get smuggled across the Macedonian border so they could go north to the rest of Europe.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: He's completely broken. He's completely--

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: I learned the rest of the story later. It wasn't just that Tarek and Hadil were all huggy and kissy around the camp. Hadil and her family are Christian. Tarek's Muslim. Hadil had only started wearing a headscarf when Tarek asked her too, as a first step toward converting for him. And the family was not cool with this.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Plus, this plan to get smuggled into Macedonia had already been underway for a while. And Hadil was suddenly saying, no, I'm staying behind with Tarek. And so they pried her out of there, beat Tarek up, bundled everybody into a bunch of cabs, and headed off to meet with a smuggler.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Tarek, alarmingly, told the police. He reported them, to keep them from leaving, which he is totally unrepentant about, except he feels bad that the smuggler got arrested. The plan was foiled, so the family turned around and headed south to a different camp. And they were gone.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: And this is where I figured the story would end. Tarek didn't want to talk to me anymore. And then a couple of days later I was at a different camp interviewing some folks with Manaf, the translator, when Ammar, our fixer who had talked with Tarek, interrupted us.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Do you feel like the foreign media is trying to cover up the talents of refugees or-- say what?

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: Just a second.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Oh, yeah-- yeah-- yeah.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: ammar saker
ep-593.utterance: I need to talk to you, and Manaf too, just for a second.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: We walk a few feet away. It's about Tarek, Ammar says. My first thought is, oh no, he's tried to kill himself, which I know sounds dramatic. And that's not what happened. Ammar says Tarek has heard from Hadil. She and her family are planning to head back to Turkey the next day, and that he needs to get to her, to get her out of there. He needs a car he says. Ammar tells him, "I don't have a car. I'm a refugee like you."

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: "Yes," says Tarek, "but you hang out with those journalists. Maybe they can help?"

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: We had heard that driving refugees around could get you in trouble with the police. There was no way we were going to do that. But then I did do something that I'm not proud of, something that, if I had thought about it a little more, I would not have done. In the next moment I heard myself say, maybe I can get him some money for a taxi. Reporters aren't supposed to get involved like this in their stories. We're supposed to observe, not intervene.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Looking back, it was a mistake. But in that moment, every reason I could think of not to help them seemed small, and almost cruel. I handed Ammar 100 euros. We all agreed he should tell Tarek it was from him and Manaf.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: I never saw Tarek. Apparently he was so happy he did a little dance. He picked up Hadil at a cafeteria near where her family was staying and brought her with him back up north to a camp near the Macedonian border. After that, I wasn't worried about ethics. I was worried about Tarek and Hadil. What if Hadil's family found them and beat Tarek up again? At the very least, they'd have to be worried sick not knowing where Hadil is. Also, I don't even know these people. I don't know if this is what's best for them, for her.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: But I've talked with Tarek and Hadil on the phone since then, and they both said things are as good as they could possibly be right now. For one thing, they're married. They had a Muslim wedding and a Christian wedding. And Tarek says he even got some money together to pay a lawyer to help them get the marriage sanctioned in Greece.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Hadil's aunt and uncle and sister never did go to Turkey. According to Tarek, they actually managed to get farther north in Europe, illegally. It's not that they're OK with the relationship, but now that it's official, they feel like they have to go along with it. Hadil's parents, though, are totally on board with it now.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: Mostly when we hear about luck in the refugee camps, it's bad luck. But of course with so many people, something has to go right for somebody. It's just the law of averages. And Tarek and Hadil beat the odds in a ridiculous way. Even just meeting each other was a slim possibility, let alone his convincing her to give him a chance and convincing a bunch of near strangers to kick him 100 euros so he could get her back.

ep-593.act_title: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
ep-593.speaker: sean cole
ep-593.utterance: A few weeks after all this, my fixer Ammar was texting with Tarek. And Tarek said, "The most ridiculous thing of all is that all these feelings of love that you have in your heart, the big sacrifices you have made and the unexpected problems, all come down to a taxi fare. It's a bastard of a feeling when you're racing against time and it's not on your side."

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: Sean Cole. Act two, Thank You for Smoking.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: People don't have a lot of money in the refugee camps. To explain people's financial situation, Joanna Kakissis, NPR's reporter in Greece who's producing these two episodes on the refugee camps with us, she explained to me that these refugees from Syria and the Mideast that we've all seen arriving on boats in Greece, she explained that they came in several distinct waves. The first wave--

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: So in early 2014 when I first started following the story, everyone I met was fairly well off. I mean--

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: All the refugees coming through.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Right. And they had paid something like between 3,000 and 5,000 euros to buy fake passports or fake IDs and fly to Germany or Sweden or wherever they were headed.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: 5,000 euros is about $5,500 American.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: And so we're talking about people who are cardiologists, people who are geophysicists, people who are big corporate managers.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: Then the second wave arrived. This is last year, 2015. And it arrived because another route from Greece into the rest of Europe opened up, what they called the Balkan route. You didn't have to pay for a smuggler. You could just walk north out of Greece using maps that people were sharing on WhatsApp. Or much easier, you could take a bus.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: So this route was actually much, much cheaper. You know, it was just a matter of buying bus tickets from one place to the other. And that's why you saw so many people coming, because suddenly it was less expensive.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: And so what kind of people were you seeing then?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Then that's when you started seeing schoolteachers, shop owners, barbers. I mean, like the best way to put it is that people with just not that much money.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: And so these were the people, when the border to the rest of Europe closed this March, these were the people who got stuck in these refugee camps. Most of them are middle class and working class families who carry the equivalent of $1,000 or $2,000, and definitely did not have enough to spring for $3,000 to $5,000 per person for a smuggler and a fake passport.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: So, they arrived without much money, and now it's been nearly five months. So to survive, lots of people get money from family overseas, wired to them, Western Union, to spend on essentials. And you can see what that means at our next stop. This is a camp that's been built on the grounds of an abandoned psychiatric hospital. It's kind of a spectacular setting at the base of Mount Olympus. So you have this snow capped mountain looming, surrounded by thick forest. Yellow paint is peeling off the old hospital buildings on the grounds-- 1,300 people living in white military tents, the Yazidi, which is a religious minority from Iraq.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: And unlike the other camps that we visited, the people here are looking for a country that's going to take all 1,300 of them. They don't want to be split up. Before the borders closed, they'd been trying to join other Yazidis who'd already made it to Germany. One of our producers, Miki Meek, visited.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: This camp is in the middle of nowhere. The closest town is about 16 miles away. Very soon after the Yazidis arrived, people began setting up their own town in the camp, slipping right back into their old jobs.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: A group of men who used to be barbers back in Iraq lined up chairs by an electrical outlet outside. Haircuts go for 2 euros. Eyebrow and beard threadings go for 1.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Three women on the other side of the camp made an oven out of a metal barrel they covered with mud. They're bakers. You can buy five pieces of naan for 1 euro.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: But the most popular spot is in a makeshift shop along a dirt path at the front of the camp. A guy named Ahmad built it. He threw it together with UNHCR tarps and old doors and shutters he found in the abandoned psychiatric hospital. He made an awning out of a thick green sleeping bag from the military. Ahmad pointed out the most popular item in his shop.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: The most selling item obviously is cigarettes. People buy cheap brands like President, Bond, Royale, and Gold. They go each for 2 and 1/2 euros.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: A pack?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: A pack, yes. So I know it's wrong. It's not healthy. But it's a very good way to calm you down.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: We here, we live in continuous stress, unknown future.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: People need a cigarette. People need to smoke right now.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Exactly. So people need to smoke, to get on with things.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: So you are smoking super lights, President. This is your brand?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I'll sell you two, two packs for 4.50 euros.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: So you're selling, selling even in an interview.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Smoking is such a part of life for men at the camp that wherever we looked, someone was smoking or offering us cigarettes. Sometimes I'd look over at my interpreter Manaf during an interview, and he'd be holding a lit cigarette in each hand. It was too rude to say no.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Lighter. Lighter.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ahmad
ep-593.utterance: Give me lighter.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Give you lighter.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: At first I thought Ahmad must be the one guy who figured out how to hustle and make money in this situation.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ahmad
ep-593.utterance: Give me euro.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: He was always pacing in front of his shop, always selling, charismatic. Then I learned he's hardly making any profit. I'm pretty sure he's running the world's only cigarette charity.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Ahmad pays to take a bus down to town a couple times a week where he loads up on cigarettes. Total cost per pack, including his bus fare, 2.35 euros a pack. And then at the camp, he turns them around and sells them for only 2.50 euros. That's just a 15 cent profit, barely covers his costs.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: He gives good deals for fruits and vegetables too. They get three meals a day from the Greek government, but they're like TV dinners, nothing fresh. So people stop by right after meals are distributed--

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ahmad
ep-593.utterance: Tomato-- tomato.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: --to make up things like eggplants, cucumbers, bananas.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: This bag of sugar as well, 89 cents.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Ahmed said he sells sugar for what it costs, because it's too much of a necessity. Everyone needs it for their tea.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: But there's a thing I started noticing. A lot of people would walk up to Ahmed during the day, silently hand him money, and then walk away from his shop without taking anything.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: There's a man right here and he just walked up and is paying Ahmad 2 and 1/2 euros.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Obviously I trusted him with the money. I wasn't there, in the shop. This month comes in, picks up what he wants. Then he goes--

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: So he's paying--

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: This is when I realized, this is not a normal store. Ahmad can leave it open and unattended, and people can take what they want on credit. They don't even leave him a note. They just tell him later.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Everyone is low on cash, even the most powerful person in the camp, the religious leader, Sheikh Nuri. Even he has to get stuff for free from Ahmad. I watched him stop by the shop after lunch.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I took some spices, onions, and tomato for free. So basically the way it goes, if I need something, I would come to the shop and take it. We're all like this. We're barely surviving. Most of us will have to borrow from Ahmad. Ahmad is ready-- Ahmad is ready to help us. Without him, I think we don't know what we would do basically.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: This camp is different from the others we visited. The Islamic State targeted these Yazidis for extinction, invaded their home in the mountains of northern Iraq, and began a mass extermination campaign, killed the men, kidnapped the women and girls, and made them sex slaves, sent the kids to ISIS training camps. Maybe you remember, these are the people President Obama helped save with airstrikes in 2014. They're survivors fleeing genocide. They're used to looking out for each other.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Ahmad said it's ingrained in them. So when people come to his shop and they can't pay, he's fine with that. He tells them to pay what they can when they can if they can. He carries a little black notebook in his fanny pack, listing each family and what they owe him.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: What does it say?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Name, Hadeato. 2 euros previously owed, plus 4 euros today for vegetables.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Marwan, another name, 13 euros owed in the past. 3 euros tomato, 2 euros onion.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: So aren't you're just losing a lot of money?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I started the shop with 500 euros as a capital. Now I have lent the equivalent of 200 euros.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: If we continue like this, obviously I can't run my shop much longer.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Back in Iraq, Ahmad also had a shop selling groceries and other stuff. And he says he made about $250 a day in profit. Now he's making $11 a day. He spends $8 on food for his family and $3 on cigarettes.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: He's here with his wife and seven kids. His store back home had backgammon, chess, and cards that men would come play at night for money. Ahmad still runs a tiny gambling den. It's in the back of his shop, lit by a couple of rechargeable UNHCR lamps that hang from the ceiling at night.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: I sat next to a young guy, 25 years old, named Haider. He says he kills about four hours every day in the back of Ahmad's shop.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: He starts laying down cards.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Did you just win?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I just scored the lowest. Basically he's won the game.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: The 50 cents everyone put into play all goes toward a bag of mixed vegetables for the winner. Or like in Haider's case, he just uses the winnings to retire some of his debt with Ahmad.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: How much money did you have when you came to Greece?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: So I had 500 euros.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: What about now?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: You're standing up and pulling money out of your pocket. So how much? How much do you have there? 3 euros. You have 3 euros.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: haider
ep-593.utterance: Yes-- yes.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I basically have 3 euros to last me three days. So Ahmad here is here to help me if I needed anything.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: This was an unusually unprofitable day for Ahmad. He was out 240 euros. He borrowed 100 euros to buy produce and given out another 140 euros on credit to different families. Also, he didn't sell much.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: Couldn't you, for a while if you had to, stop taking stuff on credit just till you got a little bit more stable?

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I think my philosophy in the shop is to be able to help others. And stopping giving things on credit is simply out of the question. Because as long as I know that I can support the minimum. So if need of my family, then the rest would obviously have to be giving as a form of assistance to others, even if they couldn't pay.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Then I would shut down the shop and just become a customer myself.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: miki meek
ep-593.utterance: He told me he'd rather go out of business than stop giving credit to people at the camp.

ep-593.act_title: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: Miki Meek. Coming up, John Oliver, Larry Wilmore, Trevor Noah, you're now on notice. Refugees are entering the fake news business. Tremble at the competition in a minute from Chicago Public Radio when our program continues.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: This American Life, I'm Ira Glass. Each week on our program, of course, we choose a theme, bring you different kinds of stories on that theme. Today's it's our second show from the refugee camps in Greece. This week, you don't have to live like a refugee. We have stories of people trying to get on with their lives even though they are stuck in a refugee camp.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: And before we go any further with our show, I just want to say an incredible team has built an interactive tour of the camps that we visited with little movies and photos and three dimensional architectural renderings. And it pains me, as a radio producer, to say the following words, to admit that seeing something might actually give you a fuller view of it, but it's true. They did a great job capturing all kinds of things about daily life that you can't actually see over the radio. It's at our website thisamericanlife.org. And this brings us to Act Three of our program, Act Three, Last Resort.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: So as we talked about a little bit in last week's program, the Greek government's response to the refugee crisis has had a lot of heart. The refugees are treated with respect. They're treated with warmth in many places that we visited. But it hasn't gone so smoothly.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: Two government agencies have had trouble sorting out who would do what. It's still disorganized. Housing conditions for the refugees nearly everywhere are substandard. One official from an international organization that is working with the Greek government told me at one point, "It's 57,000 refugees." And they said, "Compare that to the refugee situations that they deal with elsewhere." Jordan has 700,000 refugees. Lebanon has over a million. Turkey has over 2 million. "57,000 refugees, this person said, "that's a soccer game in Europe. It shouldn't be this hard."

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: So there is a camp trying to set the gold standard for what refugee camps can be in Greece. It's near a village called Myrsini on the coast of the Ionian Sea, a four hour drive west of Athens. LM Village it's called. It's a former resort, an actual beach vacation resort that went bankrupt seven years ago-- 38 bungalows, painted bright orange and yellow, each with its own bathroom and electricity and kitchenette, a little plot of grass all facing the sea with a secluded beach just for them. One of our producers said when she saw it the first time, "With a little TLC and some water in the pool, we'd all want to stay there."

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: ira glass
ep-593.utterance: So this March right after the borders closed, this beach resort refugee camp opened basically because one person, the mayor of that area, willed it into existence. Joanna went there.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: This mayor is different from other Greek mayors in one important way. This mayor's from Syria. His name's Nabil Morad. He actually made history a couple of years ago when he became the first immigrant elected mayor in Greece. And back then Nabil was focused on the typical things that mayors think about-- you know, fixing roads and street lights, marketing the region's strawberries, improving tourism.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: But as the refugee crisis unfolded in Europe and he saw so many Syrians displaced and homeless, it really got to him. He took one look at the empty beach resort in his municipality, LM Village, and he thought, why not? Why not bring them here to this beach resort?

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: You need to provide shelter in an elegant way, in a good way. You don't just stick people in tents.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: That's the message we, in this camp, want to send to the rest of Europe, that when the refugees get to you, don't forget they're people. They need to be treated with respect and with care. That's why the success of this camp is so important to me.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Nabil is the Greekest Syrian I've ever met. He moved here 27 years ago, married a Greek, served in the Greek army, works as a doctor, and runs a clinic with his Greek doctor wife, in Greece. He's so fluent in Greek he often speaks in old world slang my grandmother used to use.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Nabil knew he was the best advocate for a better lifestyle for refugees. To rally locals around his cause, Nabil, in a kind of Mr. Smith Goes to the Ionian Sea way, held a town meeting in Maria Palaiologos cafe in Myrsini. That's how small a town this is, the cafe doesn't even have a name. It's just Maria Palaiologos cafe. At least 100 people packed inside, and more spilled out onto the street.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Some of them had created an atmosphere of fear and terror about the refugees, that they're criminal, heathens, lazy.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: An old man told me about he was a buy a shotgun to keep them from getting into his home. Others were talking about rapes.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Nabil told them he wanted to bring only families, Syrian families, people like him-- no single men, no Afghans, no Pakistanis, just Syrian families. He knew his audience. He also told the group it wouldn't cost the municipality anything to host the Syrian families. The state would cover everything but trash collection.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: A week after the meeting at the cafe, he called on his municipal council to vote on the plan. It really went over. Out of 26 council members, only one voted no.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Here's how desperate the Greek government is to get people set up in camps. It took them less than a week. In fact, just four days after the vote, buses filled with Syrians, over 300, arrived at the abandoned beach resort. Nabil and his family were there, some local councilors too. Remember, Nabil had promised that only families would come live at the resort. Nabil hoped that was true.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Well, we were very nervous because we didn't know who got in. Since things were done in a hurry, I didn't know what to expect. Who will I find on the buses?

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: The whole village had gathered. There was some that came out of love. And there was a group against my decision for the center, waiting to see so they could protest more. They wanted to reaffirm their lies using the first image of the refugees. They always say the same.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: If they are men, they will steal, kill, and rape. When they saw, just as I did, the children that were coming out of the buses first, at this point I relaxed. The crowd started hugging the children. Some of them started smiling.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Nabil remembers meeting a baby who was just five days old.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: She was in a little basket. I got close to the family. When I went close, I said in Arabic, "Hello, how are you doing." They understood who I was. The mother took the baby, put it in my hands. I melted. I melted. My knees were shaking from holding her.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: [SPEAKING ARABIC] You were moved I said.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Very, very.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I understood her mother who gave birth alone in a hospital and didn't even know the language, with no one of her people there to wish well for the child in Arabic.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: That's why I was so moved.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: This camp is meant to be better than other camps, and it is. There are kids on BMX bikes. There are soccer and basketball games. There's a trampoline and ping pong. Men play chess on a lawn with a view of the sea. The beach is to the west, so there's a sunset on the water every day.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Sometimes a group of friends, women, dress up in beautiful printed velour dresses that cover them from head to toe, just to go for a walk on the paved empty road lined with ornate old fashioned lampposts.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: The Syrians told me that after finally making it to Greece and sleeping in tents, pitched on streets, in field, in the mud, they were relieved to get here and rest on beds and actual homes with their own bathrooms. One woman told me she hadn't had a full night's sleep in months until she got here.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: The camp has been open now for four months. And Nabil never expected how demanding it would be. He's the one who recruited volunteers, organized doctors and midwives, called in immigration lawyers, got supplies donated. And then when the refugees arrived, he realized a critical oversight. He brought hundreds of people who only speak Arabic to a rural area where the only other person for miles who also spoke Arabic was him, Nabil, which meant that he's the person who explains that the food is not rotten or where to buy Halal meat or which direction Mecca is.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: The Syrians ask him to help them get papers to go to Germany. They ask him if EU leaders are going to fly them out of the local airport. Sometimes when someone needs to get to Athens for asylum interviews and doesn't have a ride, he'll buy the bus ticket himself. He gets calls from the camp all the time, day or night. The Syrians ask him everything, including-- because remember, Nabil is not only the mayor, he's also a doctor-- they ask him lots of questions about their health.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Like here he is walking around the camp just saying hello to two women. One of them says her friend is very tired. The friend says her body and throat hurt. Nabil checks her throat.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: You need antibiotics, he says, and sends her to the camp medical station. This is all on top of him having to run his clinic full time. And being mayor is a big job. He manages 22 towns in his municipality. He calls this camp, LM Village, his 23rd town.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: I live in Greece, and I can tell you that the refugee crisis has created a whole new sense of obligation. Whenever I interview Greeks about the refugees or when I talk to my relatives and friends and neighbors, one thing always comes across. People want to help them. There's a word in Greek, [GREEK]. There's no equivalent in English. But in essence it means be generous and do good. It's a point of national pride, of Greek character and culture.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: But after a six year economic crisis so many Greeks are broke or barely getting by, Greeks are also thinking it's a very real possibility that I could soon be destitute myself. And how can I help then? How can we help so many displaced people now living with us?

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: And you see both these impulses, [GREEK] and fear, in Myrsini, the town next to LM Village. On the one hand, the locals I spoke with said most people don't have a problem with the Syrians. They're happy that these families with little kids are secure and safe. The vice president of the town, for example, told me he spends all day with the Syrians and he sees real needs there.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: But he also sees needs all around him, even his own neighbor, a 70-year-old woman he's known his whole life. She's now so broke she's washing her hair with Tide. Or there's Nikos who's 43, and like a quarter of Greeks, unemployed. He used to work in construction. When I'd met him, he'd been out of work for a while and he didn't have health insurance. And he expressed real and understandable resentment.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I don't have the money to pay. So I'll have to stay uninsured. If something happens to me and I have to go to the hospital, I will owe money.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: A foreigner doesn't have these problems. It's not fair.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Refugees can go to the hospital for free. Sometimes I've noticed that local resentment toward the camp is less personal and more outright xenophobic.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Occasionally the rumors get really overblown. My producer Robyn Semien and I spoke to Alexandra Altouni. She's the councilwoman who voted against the camp in the first place.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: I heard of what they say is, well, you know. You guys, you Greeks are supposed to take care of us. We're not going to do anything here because we don't have to. We gave them a place to stay, to eat. The Red Cross is helping them. We took them to the doctors, gynecologists.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: We've even given them birth control pills so they won't have more kids. So I ask, because theoretically there are women and children here, why do they need birth control pills? Because lots of things have been told. There are lots of rumors going around.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Rumors that involve sex and money.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Do you believe these rumors that the women are prostitutes?

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: It could be a lie. But I really want to know why they need birth control pills if they don't have men. But you know, this is what I think. I think--

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: --if they're coming from a war zone and theoretically they're damaged people and they're worried about what's next for them, why do they even care about sex? Why should that even be an issue for them?

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: It's not true that most of the women are there without their husbands. And of course it's not true that they're prostitutes. Alexandra resents Nabil for bringing the refugees here. She sees the camp as a betrayal to the Greeks who supported him.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: We didn't see him as a Syrian when we voted for him. We supported him more than we would have a Greek, a Greek Greek, a real Greek. How can I say it? We saw him as Greek. He's not Greek. He's a guest here.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Four months in, many of the Syrians still seem to like and appreciate Nabil. I've been there four times, and for the most part, the Syrians are OK with the camp, just like the Greeks who live around it. There is also a small but very vocal minority that's frustrated and angry and blaming Nabil.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: To give you a sense of how intense this can be, the first week in June, I stopped by the camp late one Sunday night with my interpreter, Roula. They heard her accent, and then they knew that she's also Syrian. She was instantly surrounded by a crowd.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: They wanted to talk about Nabil, to complain about him.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: There's lots of mosquitoes here. Can you do something about it? All of the children here, they have plenty of rashes because of mosquitoes.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: interpreter
ep-593.utterance: Would he accept that if his children would live like this.

ep-593.act_title: Act Three: Last Resort
ep-593.speaker: joanna kakissis
ep-593.utterance: Someone else complains they found worms in the water tank on the property. There had been a protest. Some refused to eat. They said Nabil didn't do enough. Also--
